home.title: Go Tutorial
paragraphs: Go is a popular programming language.
Go is used to create computer programs.
Start learning Go now.

sections.heading: What is Go?
paragraphs: Go is a cross-platform, open-source programming language.
Go can be used to create high-performance applications.
Go is a fast, statically typed, compiled language known for its simplicity and efficiency.
Go was developed at Google by Robert Griesemer, Rob Pike, and Ken Thompson in 2007.
Go's syntax is similar to C++.

sections.heading: What is Go Used For?
paragraphs: Web development (server-side).
Developing network-based programs.
Developing cross-platform enterprise applications.
Cloud-native development.

sections.heading: Why Use Go?
paragraphs: Go is fun and easy to learn.
Go has fast runtime and compilation time.
Go supports concurrency.
Go has built-in memory management.
Go works on multiple platforms like Windows, Mac, Linux, and Raspberry Pi.

sections.heading: Go Compared to Python and C++
Notes
paragraphs: Compilation time means converting code into an executable program.
Concurrency means performing multiple tasks at the same time.
Statically typed means variable types are known at compile time.

sections.heading: What You Need
paragraphs: To start using Go, you need a text editor and a compiler.
Popular editors include VS Code, Vim, Eclipse, and Notepad.
In this tutorial, we will use an IDE to write and compile Go code.

sections.heading: Install Go
paragraphs: Download Go from the official website at https://golang.org/dl/.
Follow the installation instructions for your operating system.
To verify installation, run the command: go version.
sections.code: go version

sections.heading: Install an IDE
paragraphs: An IDE is used to edit, compile, and debug code.
Popular IDEs for Go include Visual Studio Code, Vim, Eclipse, and Notepad.
VS Code is recommended for beginners.

sections.heading: Configure Go in VS Code
steps: Search for 'Go' and install the Go extension by Google.
Open the Command Palette (Ctrl + Shift + P).
Run 'Go: Install/Update Tools' and install all tools.

sections.heading: Your First Go Program
paragraphs: Create a new file named helloworld.go.
Write the following code:

sections.heading: Run the Program
paragraphs: Open the terminal in VS Code and run the program.
sections.code: go run .\helloworld.go

sections.heading: Build an Executable
paragraphs: To save the program as an executable, use the build command.
sections.code: go build .\helloworld.go

sections.heading: Go Program Structure
paragraphs: A Go file consists of several basic parts.
These parts define how a Go program is written and executed.

sections.heading: Example
Example Explained
paragraphs: Every Go program belongs to a package. The main package is required for executable programs.
The import statement is used to include packages, such as fmt, which provides input and output functions.
Whitespace and blank lines are ignored by Go, but they improve readability.
The main() function is the entry point of the program.
fmt.Println() prints output to the console.

sections.heading: Go Statements
paragraphs: A statement is an instruction that performs an action.
In Go, statements end at the end of a line or with a semicolon.
The compiler automatically inserts semicolons at the end of lines.
The opening curly brace { must be on the same line as the function declaration.

sections.heading: Invalid Syntax Example
paragraphs: The following code will cause an error because the opening brace is placed on a new line.

sections.heading: Compact Code
paragraphs: Go allows writing compact code using semicolons.
This style is not recommended because it reduces readability.
sections.code: package main; import ("fmt"); func main() { fmt.Println("Hello World!"); }

sections.heading: Exercise
paragraphs: Insert the missing part of the code to output "Hello World".

exercise.question: Complete the code to print Hello World.

sections.heading: What are Comments?
paragraphs: A comment is a text that is ignored during program execution.
Comments are used to explain code and make it more readable.
They can also be used to prevent code execution during testing.

sections.heading: Types of Comments in Go
paragraphs: Go supports single-line comments and multi-line comments.

sections.heading: Single-line Comments
paragraphs: Single-line comments start with two forward slashes (//).
Any text after // on the same line is ignored by the compiler.

sections.heading: Single-line Comment at End of Line
paragraphs: Single-line comments can also be written at the end of a code line.

sections.heading: Multi-line Comments
paragraphs: Multi-line comments start with /* and end with */.
Any text between them is ignored by the compiler.

sections.heading: Using Comments to Disable Code
paragraphs: Comments can be used to prevent code from being executed.
This is useful for testing or saving code for later use.

sections.heading: Tip
paragraphs: Use // for short comments.
Use /* */ for longer explanations.

sections.heading: Introduction to Variables
paragraphs: Variables are used to store data values in a program.
In Go, every variable must be declared before it can be used.

sections.heading: Common Variable Types
paragraphs: Go supports several basic data types.
int is used for whole numbers, float32 for decimal values, string for text, and bool for true or false values.

sections.heading: Declaring Variables with var
paragraphs: The var keyword is used to declare variables in Go.
You can specify the variable name along with its type and value.
sections.code: var age int = 20

sections.heading: Declaring Variables with :=
paragraphs: The := operator is a shorthand way to declare variables.
The compiler automatically determines the variable type from the value.
This method can only be used inside functions.
sections.code: age := 20

sections.heading: Variables with Initial Values
paragraphs: When the value is known in advance, a variable can be declared and initialized in one line.

sections.heading: Variables Without Initial Values
paragraphs: In Go, variables always have a default value.
If no value is assigned, Go automatically assigns a default value based on the variable type.

sections.heading: Assigning Values Later
paragraphs: You can assign a value to a variable after declaring it.
This is useful when the value is not known at the beginning of the program.

sections.heading: Multiple Variable Declaration
paragraphs: Go allows declaring multiple variables in a single statement.
This helps reduce repetition and makes the code cleaner.

sections.heading: Multiple Variables Without Type
paragraphs: When the type is not specified, Go infers the type from the values.
Different types can be declared on the same line.

sections.heading: Variable Declaration in a Block
paragraphs: Multiple variables can be grouped together using a declaration block.
This improves readability when working with many variables.

sections.heading: Variable Naming Rules
paragraphs: A variable name in Go can be short or descriptive.
Using clear and meaningful names makes code easier to read and maintain.

sections.heading: Rules for Naming Variables
paragraphs: A variable name must start with a letter or an underscore (_).
A variable name cannot start with a digit.
Only letters, numbers, and underscores are allowed.
Variable names are case-sensitive.
Variable names cannot contain spaces.
Go keywords cannot be used as variable names.
There is no fixed limit on the length of a variable name.

sections.heading: Multi-Word Variable Names
paragraphs: Variable names with multiple words should be written in a readable format.
Go developers follow specific naming styles to improve clarity.

sections.heading: Camel Case
paragraphs: In camel case, the first word starts with a lowercase letter.
Each subsequent word starts with an uppercase letter.
sections.code: myVariableName := "John"

sections.heading: Pascal Case
paragraphs: In Pascal case, every word starts with an uppercase letter.
This style is commonly used for exported names in Go.
sections.code: MyVariableName := "John"

sections.heading: Snake Case
paragraphs: In snake case, words are separated using underscores.
This style is valid but less common in Go programming.
sections.code: my_variable_name := "John"

sections.heading: What are Constants?
paragraphs: Constants are variables whose values cannot be changed once assigned.
In Go, constants are declared using the const keyword.
Constants are read-only and remain fixed throughout the program.

sections.heading: Declaring a Constant
paragraphs: A constant must be assigned a value at the time of declaration.
The value of a constant cannot be modified later.

sections.heading: Constant Naming Rules
paragraphs: Constant names follow the same naming rules as variables.
By convention, constant names are written in uppercase letters.
Constants can be declared both inside and outside functions.

sections.heading: Types of Constants
paragraphs: Go supports two types of constants: typed constants and untyped constants.

sections.heading: Typed Constants
paragraphs: Typed constants are declared with a specific data type.
The constant value must match the declared type.

sections.heading: Untyped Constants
paragraphs: Untyped constants are declared without specifying a type.
The compiler automatically infers the type from the assigned value.

sections.heading: Constants are Unchangeable
paragraphs: Once a constant is declared, its value cannot be changed.
Attempting to modify a constant will result in a compilation error.

sections.heading: Multiple Constant Declaration
paragraphs: Multiple constants can be grouped together using a constant block.
This improves readability when declaring many constants.

sections.heading: Output in Go
paragraphs: Go provides built-in functions to display output on the screen.
The most commonly used output functions are Print(), Println(), and Printf().

sections.heading: The Print() Function
paragraphs: The Print() function prints its arguments using their default format.
It does not automatically add a space or a new line at the end.

sections.heading: Printing on New Lines
paragraphs: To print output on a new line using Print(), you can use the newline character \n.
The newline character forces the output to move to the next line.

sections.heading: Printing Multiple Values
paragraphs: Multiple values can be printed using a single Print() function.
You can also manually add spaces between values when needed.

sections.heading: Automatic Spacing with Numbers
paragraphs: When printing non-string values, Print() automatically inserts a space between arguments.

sections.heading: The Println() Function
paragraphs: The Println() function works like Print(), but it adds a space between arguments.
It also adds a newline at the end of the output automatically.

sections.heading: The Printf() Function
paragraphs: The Printf() function formats output based on format specifiers.
It allows precise control over how values are displayed.

sections.heading: Formatting Verbs
paragraphs: %v is used to print the value of a variable.
%T is used to print the type of a variable.
Go provides many formatting verbs for different output needs.

sections.heading: Formatting Verbs in Go
paragraphs: Go provides formatting verbs that work with the Printf() function.
Formatting verbs control how values are displayed in the output.

sections.heading: General Formatting Verbs
paragraphs: %v prints the value in its default format.
%#v prints the value in Go syntax format.
%T prints the data type of the value.
%% prints a literal percent sign.
sections.code:
package main
import ("fmt")

func main() {
  var i = 15.5
  var txt = "Hello World!"

  fmt.Printf("%v\n", i)
  fmt.Printf("%#v\n", i)
  fmt.Printf("%v%%\n", i)
  fmt.Printf("%T\n", i)

  fmt.Printf("%v\n", txt)
  fmt.Printf("%#v\n", txt)
  fmt.Printf("%T\n", txt)
}

sections.heading: Integer Formatting Verbs
paragraphs: Go provides several formatting verbs for integer values.
%b prints the value in binary format.
%d prints the value in decimal format.
%o prints the value in octal format.
%x and %X print the value in hexadecimal format.
sections.code:
package main
import ("fmt")

func main() {
  var i = 15

  fmt.Printf("%b\n", i)
  fmt.Printf("%d\n", i)
  fmt.Printf("%+d\n", i)
  fmt.Printf("%o\n", i)
  fmt.Printf("%x\n", i)
  fmt.Printf("%X\n", i)
}

sections.heading: String Formatting Verbs
paragraphs: %s prints the value as a plain string.
%q prints the value as a double-quoted string.
Width can be specified to align strings in output.

sections.heading: Boolean Formatting Verbs
paragraphs: %t prints the boolean value as true or false.

sections.heading: Float Formatting Verbs
paragraphs: %f prints a decimal number.
%.2f prints a decimal number with two digits after the decimal point.
%e prints the number in scientific notation.
%g prints the value using the shortest representation.

sections.heading: What are Data Types?
paragraphs: A data type specifies the type and size of data a variable can store.
Data types help the compiler understand how much memory to allocate and how to interpret the stored value.

sections.heading: Static Typing in Go
paragraphs: Go is a statically typed language.
Once a variable is declared with a specific type, it can only store values of that type.

sections.heading: Basic Data Types in Go
paragraphs: Go has three main categories of basic data types.
These include boolean values, numeric values, and string values.

sections.heading: Boolean Data Type
paragraphs: The bool data type represents a boolean value.
It can only store true or false.
sections.code: var isActive bool = true

sections.heading: Numeric Data Types
paragraphs: Numeric data types are used to store numbers.
They include integer types and floating-point types.

sections.heading: Integer Data Type
paragraphs: Integer data types store whole numbers.
Common integer types include int, int8, int16, int32, and int64.
sections.code: var count int = 5

sections.heading: Floating Point Data Type
paragraphs: Floating point data types store numbers with decimal points.
Common floating-point types are float32 and float64.
sections.code: var price float32 = 3.14

sections.heading: String Data Type
paragraphs: The string data type is used to store text.
String values are written inside double quotes.
sections.code: var message string = "Hi!"

sections.heading: Example: Using Multiple Data Types
paragraphs: The following example demonstrates how different data types are used in a Go program.
sections.code:
package main
import ("fmt")

func main() {
  var a bool = true
  var b int = 5
  var c float32 = 3.14
  var d string = "Hi!"

  fmt.Println("Boolean:", a)
  fmt.Println("Integer:", b)
  fmt.Println("Float:", c)
  fmt.Println("String:", d)
}

sections.heading: Boolean Data Type
paragraphs: The boolean data type in Go is declared using the bool keyword.
A boolean variable can store only two values: true or false.

sections.heading: Default Value of Boolean
paragraphs: The default value of a boolean variable in Go is false.
If a boolean variable is declared without an initial value, it automatically becomes false.

sections.heading: Declaring Boolean Variables
paragraphs: Boolean variables can be declared in multiple ways.
They can be declared with or without specifying the type.
sections.code:
package main
import ("fmt")

func main() {
  var b1 bool = true   // typed declaration with initial value
  var b2 = true        // untyped declaration with initial value
  var b3 bool          // typed declaration without initial value
  b4 := true           // short declaration

  fmt.Println(b1)
  fmt.Println(b2)
  fmt.Println(b3)
  fmt.Println(b4)
}

sections.heading: Using Boolean Values
paragraphs: Boolean values are commonly used in conditional statements.
They help control the flow of execution in programs.

sections.heading: Integer Data Types
paragraphs: Integer data types are used to store whole numbers without decimal points.
Examples include positive numbers, negative numbers, and zero.

sections.heading: Signed and Unsigned Integers
paragraphs: Go supports two categories of integer data types: signed and unsigned.
Signed integers can store both positive and negative values.
Unsigned integers can store only non-negative values.

sections.heading: Default Integer Type
paragraphs: The default integer type in Go is int.
If no integer type is specified, Go automatically uses int.

sections.heading: Signed Integers
paragraphs: Signed integers are declared using int keywords.
They can store both positive and negative values.

sections.heading: Signed Integer Types
paragraphs: Go provides several signed integer types with different sizes.
Common signed integer types include int8, int16, int32, and int64.
The size of int depends on the system architecture.

sections.heading: Unsigned Integers
paragraphs: Unsigned integers are declared using uint keywords.
They can store only zero and positive values.

sections.heading: Unsigned Integer Types
paragraphs: Common unsigned integer types include uint8, uint16, uint32, and uint64.
Unsigned integers are useful when negative values are not required.

sections.heading: Choosing the Right Integer Type
paragraphs: The integer type you choose depends on the range of values you need to store.
Using a type with insufficient range will cause a compilation error.

sections.heading: Float Data Types
paragraphs: Float data types are used to store numbers with decimal points.
They can store both positive and negative decimal values.

sections.heading: Types of Float in Go
paragraphs: Go provides two floating-point data types: float32 and float64.
float32 uses 32 bits of memory, while float64 uses 64 bits of memory.

sections.heading: Default Float Type
paragraphs: The default floating-point type in Go is float64.
If no float type is specified, Go automatically uses float64.

sections.heading: Using float32
paragraphs: The float32 type is used when memory usage needs to be optimized.
It has a smaller range compared to float64.

sections.heading: Using float64
paragraphs: The float64 data type can store a much larger range of values than float32.
It is commonly used for most decimal calculations.

sections.heading: Choosing the Right Float Type
paragraphs: The choice between float32 and float64 depends on the required range and precision.
Using a value outside the allowed range will result in a compilation error.

sections.heading: String Data Type
paragraphs: The string data type is used to store a sequence of characters.
String values in Go must be enclosed within double quotes.

sections.heading: Declaring String Variables
paragraphs: String variables can be declared with or without an initial value.
If a string variable is declared without a value, its default value is an empty string.

sections.heading: Default Value of String
paragraphs: The default value of a string variable in Go is an empty string.
An empty string does not contain any characters.

sections.heading: What are Arrays?
paragraphs: Arrays are used to store multiple values of the same type in a single variable.
Instead of declaring many variables, arrays allow data to be grouped together.

sections.heading: Declaring Arrays
paragraphs: In Go, arrays have a fixed length.
The length can be explicitly defined or inferred by the compiler.

sections.heading: Array Declaration with var
paragraphs: Arrays can be declared using the var keyword.
The length can be specified or inferred using three dots (...).

sections.heading: Array Declaration with :=
paragraphs: Arrays can also be declared using the := shorthand syntax.
This method is commonly used inside functions.

sections.heading: Array Examples
paragraphs: Arrays can store values of any data type.
The following example shows integer and string arrays.

sections.heading: Accessing Array Elements
paragraphs: Array elements are accessed using index numbers.
Indexes start from 0, where index 0 refers to the first element.

sections.heading: Changing Array Elements
paragraphs: Array values can be modified by assigning a new value to an index.
The index position determines which element is changed.

sections.heading: Array Initialization
paragraphs: If array elements are not initialized, they receive default values.
The default value for int is 0 and for string is an empty string.

sections.heading: Initializing Specific Elements
paragraphs: Specific array elements can be initialized using index positions.
Other elements will receive default values.

sections.heading: Finding the Length of an Array
paragraphs: The len() function is used to determine the number of elements in an array.

sections.heading: What are Slices?
paragraphs: Slices are similar to arrays, but are more powerful and flexible.
Like arrays, slices store multiple values of the same type in a single variable.
Unlike arrays, slices can grow and shrink dynamically.

sections.heading: Creating a Slice
paragraphs: There are multiple ways to create a slice in Go.
The most common method is using the []datatype{values} format.
sections.code:
myslice := []int{}
myslice2 := []int{1, 2, 3}

sections.heading: Length and Capacity
paragraphs: Go provides built-in functions to work with slices.
len() returns the number of elements in the slice.
cap() returns the capacity of the slice.

sections.heading: Slice Example
paragraphs: If no elements are provided, both length and capacity will be zero.
When elements are provided, length and capacity match the number of elements.

sections.heading: Creating a Slice from an Array
paragraphs: A slice can be created from an existing array.
The slice references a portion of the array.

sections.heading: Understanding Slice Capacity
paragraphs: The capacity of a slice depends on where it starts in the array.
The slice can grow until it reaches the end of the underlying array.

sections.heading: Creating a Slice Using make()
paragraphs: The make() function can be used to create slices.
It allows you to specify length and capacity.
sections.code:
package main
import ("fmt")

func main() {
  s1 := make([]int, 5, 10)
  fmt.Println(s1)
  fmt.Println(len(s1))
  fmt.Println(cap(s1))

  s2 := make([]int, 5)
  fmt.Println(s2)
  fmt.Println(len(s2))
  fmt.Println(cap(s2))
}

sections.heading: Access Elements of a Slice
paragraphs: You can access slice elements using index numbers.
Slice indexes start from 0.

sections.heading: Change Elements of a Slice
paragraphs: Slice elements can be modified using their index.
This directly updates the slice value.

sections.heading: Append Elements to a Slice
paragraphs: The append() function is used to add elements to a slice.
Appending may increase the slice capacity.

sections.heading: Append One Slice to Another
paragraphs: You can append all elements of one slice into another.
The ... operator is required.

sections.heading: Changing Slice Length
paragraphs: Slices can be resized by re-slicing or appending elements.
Re-slicing does not allocate new memory.

sections.heading: Copying Slices
paragraphs: The copy() function creates a new slice with its own memory.
This is useful for memory efficiency when working with large slices.

sections.heading: What are Operators?
paragraphs: Operators are used to perform operations on variables and values.
They allow you to manipulate data, compare values, and control program logic.

sections.heading: Addition Operator (+)
paragraphs: The + operator is used to add two values.
It can be used with constants, variables, or a combination of both.

sections.heading: Using Variables with + Operator
paragraphs: The + operator can also be used to add variables and expressions.
Values are evaluated from left to right.

sections.heading: Types of Operators in Go
paragraphs: Go provides different categories of operators.
Each category is used for a specific type of operation.

sections.heading: What are Arithmetic Operators?
paragraphs: Arithmetic operators are used to perform mathematical operations.
They work with numeric values such as integers and floating-point numbers.

sections.heading: Addition Operator (+)
paragraphs: The addition operator adds two values.

sections.heading: Subtraction Operator (-)
paragraphs: The subtraction operator subtracts one value from another.

sections.heading: Multiplication Operator (*)
paragraphs: The multiplication operator multiplies two values.

sections.heading: Division Operator (/)
paragraphs: The division operator divides one value by another.
When dividing integers, the result will also be an integer.

sections.heading: Modulus Operator (%)
paragraphs: The modulus operator returns the remainder of a division.

sections.heading: Increment Operator (++)
paragraphs: The increment operator increases the value of a variable by 1.
It can only be used with variables.

sections.heading: Decrement Operator (--)
paragraphs: The decrement operator decreases the value of a variable by 1.
It can only be used with variables.

sections.heading: What are Assignment Operators?
paragraphs: Assignment operators are used to assign values to variables.
They can also combine assignment with arithmetic or bitwise operations.

sections.heading: Simple Assignment Operator (=)
paragraphs: The equals operator assigns a value to a variable.

sections.heading: Addition Assignment Operator (+=)
paragraphs: The += operator adds a value to the variable and assigns the result.

sections.heading: Subtraction Assignment Operator (-=)
paragraphs: The -= operator subtracts a value from the variable.

sections.heading: Multiplication Assignment Operator (*=)
paragraphs: The *= operator multiplies the variable by a value.

sections.heading: Division Assignment Operator (/=)
paragraphs: The /= operator divides the variable by a value.

sections.heading: Modulus Assignment Operator (%=)
paragraphs: The %= operator assigns the remainder of a division to the variable.

sections.heading: Bitwise Assignment Operators
paragraphs: Go also supports bitwise assignment operators.
These operators combine bitwise operations with assignment.

sections.heading: Shift Assignment Operators
paragraphs: Shift assignment operators shift bits and assign the result.
<<= shifts bits to the left, and >>= shifts bits to the right.

sections.heading: What are Comparison Operators?
paragraphs: Comparison operators are used to compare two values.
The result of a comparison is always a boolean value: true or false.

sections.heading: Greater Than Operator (>)
paragraphs: The greater than operator checks if one value is larger than another.

sections.heading: Equal To Operator (==)
paragraphs: The == operator checks whether two values are equal.

sections.heading: Not Equal To Operator (!=)
paragraphs: The != operator checks whether two values are not equal.

sections.heading: Less Than Operator (<)
paragraphs: The less than operator checks if one value is smaller than another.

sections.heading: Greater Than or Equal To Operator (>=)
paragraphs: The >= operator checks if a value is greater than or equal to another value.

sections.heading: Less Than or Equal To Operator (<=)
paragraphs: The <= operator checks if a value is less than or equal to another value.

sections.heading: Comparison Operators in Conditions
paragraphs: Comparison operators are commonly used in conditional statements.
You will learn more about this in the Go Conditions chapter.

sections.heading: What are Logical Operators?
paragraphs: Logical operators are used to combine or modify boolean expressions.
They return either true or false based on the logic applied.

sections.heading: Logical AND (&&)
paragraphs: The logical AND operator returns true only if both conditions are true.

sections.heading: Logical OR (||)
paragraphs: The logical OR operator returns true if at least one condition is true.

sections.heading: Logical NOT (!)
paragraphs: The logical NOT operator reverses the result of a condition.
If the condition is true, it returns false, and vice versa.

sections.heading: Using Logical Operators in Conditions
paragraphs: Logical operators are commonly used in if statements and loops.
They help build complex conditions in a readable way.

sections.heading: What are Bitwise Operators?
paragraphs: Bitwise operators work on numbers at the binary level.
They perform operations on individual bits of integer values.

sections.heading: Bitwise AND (&)
paragraphs: The bitwise AND operator sets a bit to 1 only if both corresponding bits are 1.

sections.heading: Bitwise OR (|)
paragraphs: The bitwise OR operator sets a bit to 1 if at least one of the corresponding bits is 1.

sections.heading: Bitwise XOR (^)
paragraphs: The bitwise XOR operator sets a bit to 1 only if the bits are different.

sections.heading: Left Shift (<<)
paragraphs: The left shift operator shifts bits to the left and fills the right side with zeros.
Each left shift doubles the number.

sections.heading: Right Shift (>>)
paragraphs: The right shift operator shifts bits to the right.
Each right shift halves the number.

sections.heading: When to Use Bitwise Operators
paragraphs: Bitwise operators are commonly used in low-level programming.
They are useful for performance optimization, flags, and binary data manipulation.

sections.heading: What are Conditional Statements?
paragraphs: Conditional statements are used to perform different actions based on different conditions.
A condition in Go always evaluates to either true or false.

sections.heading: Comparison Operators in Conditions
paragraphs: Go supports common comparison operators used to compare values.
These operators are often used to form conditions.

sections.heading: Logical Operators in Conditions
paragraphs: Logical operators are used to combine multiple conditions.
They help build more complex decision-making logic.

sections.heading: Using Conditions
paragraphs: Conditions are created by combining comparison and logical operators.
They control the flow of execution in a program.

sections.heading: Types of Conditional Statements in Go
paragraphs: Go provides several conditional statements to control program flow.

sections.heading: What is an if Statement?
paragraphs: The if statement is used to execute a block of code only when a specified condition is true.
If the condition evaluates to false, the code inside the if block is skipped.

sections.heading: Syntax of if Statement
paragraphs: The if keyword must be written in lowercase.
Curly braces are mandatory in Go, even for a single statement.

sections.heading: Simple if Example
paragraphs: In this example, the condition checks whether 20 is greater than 18.
Since the condition is true, the message is printed.

sections.heading: Using Variables in if Statement
paragraphs: Conditions often involve variables instead of fixed values.
The comparison operator decides whether the code block should run.

sections.heading: How the if Statement Works
paragraphs: The condition inside the if statement is evaluated first.
If the condition is true, the code inside the block executes.
If the condition is false, the block is skipped entirely.

sections.heading: Practice Example
paragraphs: This example prints a message only when x is greater than y.

sections.heading: What is an if else Statement?
paragraphs: The if else statement is used to execute one block of code if a condition is true and another block if the condition is false.
It allows a program to make decisions between two alternatives.

sections.heading: Syntax of if else Statement
paragraphs: The else block runs only when the if condition evaluates to false.
The else keyword must be written on the same line as the closing brace of the if block.

sections.heading: Basic if else Example
paragraphs: In this example, the program checks the value of time.
Since time is greater than 18, the if condition becomes false and the else block executes.

sections.heading: Another if else Example
paragraphs: Here, the temperature is checked to determine whether it is warm or cold.
If the condition fails, the else block is executed.

sections.heading: Important Syntax Rule
paragraphs: In Go, the else keyword must be placed on the same line as the closing brace of the if block.
Placing else on a new line will cause a syntax error.

sections.heading: Incorrect if else Syntax Example
paragraphs: This example demonstrates an incorrect placement of the else keyword.
The program will fail to compile due to a syntax error.

sections.heading: What is an else if Statement?
paragraphs: The else if statement is used to check a new condition when the previous if condition is false.
It allows multiple conditions to be tested sequentially.

sections.heading: Syntax of else if Statement
paragraphs: Conditions are checked from top to bottom.
As soon as one condition evaluates to true, its block of code is executed and the remaining conditions are skipped.

sections.heading: Basic else if Example
paragraphs: In this example, the program checks the value of time.
Since time is greater than both 10 and 20, the else block is executed.

sections.heading: else if with Comparison Example
paragraphs: This example compares two variables to determine their relationship.
If none of the first two conditions are true, the else block is executed.

sections.heading: Important Rule of else if
paragraphs: Only the first true condition is executed.
Even if multiple conditions are true, Go executes only the first matching block.

sections.heading: Condition Priority Example
paragraphs: In this example, both conditions are true.
However, only the first condition is executed because it appears first.

sections.heading: What is a Nested if Statement?
paragraphs: A nested if statement means placing one if statement inside another if statement.
It is used when a condition depends on another condition being true first.

sections.heading: Syntax of Nested if
paragraphs: The inner if statement is executed only when the outer if condition is true.

sections.heading: Nested if Example
paragraphs: In this example, the program first checks if the number is greater than or equal to 10.
If that condition is true, it then checks whether the number is greater than 15.

sections.heading: How Nested if Works
paragraphs: The outer if condition is evaluated first.
If the outer condition is false, the inner if block is skipped.
Nested if statements help handle complex decision-making scenarios.

sections.heading: What is a switch Statement?
paragraphs: The switch statement is used to select one of many code blocks to be executed.
In Go, the switch statement runs only the matched case and does not require a break statement.

sections.heading: How switch Works
paragraphs: The switch expression is evaluated once.
The result is compared with each case value.
When a match is found, the corresponding code block is executed.
The default case runs if no case matches.

sections.heading: Syntax of switch
paragraphs: Each case must have the same data type as the switch expression.
The default case is optional.

sections.heading: Single-Case switch Example
paragraphs: This example uses a number to determine the day of the week.
sections.code:
package main
import ("fmt")

func main() {
  day := 4

  switch day {
  case 1:
    fmt.Println("Monday")
  case 2:
    fmt.Println("Tuesday")
  case 3:
    fmt.Println("Wednesday")
  case 4:
    fmt.Println("Thursday")
  case 5:
    fmt.Println("Friday")
  case 6:
    fmt.Println("Saturday")
  case 7:
    fmt.Println("Sunday")
  }
}

sections.heading: Using the default Case
paragraphs: The default case executes when no case value matches the switch expression.
sections.code:
package main
import ("fmt")

func main() {
  day := 8

  switch day {
  case 1:
    fmt.Println("Monday")
  case 2:
    fmt.Println("Tuesday")
  case 3:
    fmt.Println("Wednesday")
  case 4:
    fmt.Println("Thursday")
  case 5:
    fmt.Println("Friday")
  case 6:
    fmt.Println("Saturday")
  case 7:
    fmt.Println("Sunday")
  default:
    fmt.Println("Not a weekday")
  }
}

sections.heading: Type Safety in switch
paragraphs: All case values must be of the same type as the switch expression.
Using mismatched types will result in a compiler error.

sections.heading: What is a Multi-case switch?
paragraphs: A multi-case switch allows multiple values to be handled by a single case.
This helps reduce duplicate code and makes the switch statement more readable.

sections.heading: Syntax of Multi-case switch
paragraphs: You can separate multiple case values using commas.
If the switch expression matches any of the listed values, the case block is executed.

sections.heading: Multi-case switch Example
paragraphs: This example categorizes days into odd weekdays, even weekdays, and weekends.

sections.heading: Why Use Multi-case switch?
paragraphs: It reduces repetitive code when multiple values require the same logic.
It improves code readability and organization.
It is commonly used for grouping related values.

sections.heading: Introduction to Go For Loop
paragraphs: The for loop is used to execute a block of code multiple times.
In Go, the for loop is the only looping construct available.
Each repetition of the loop is called an iteration.

sections.heading: For Loop Syntax
paragraphs: A for loop can contain up to three statements.
These statements control how the loop starts, continues, and updates.

sections.heading: Statements Explained
paragraphs: statement1 initializes the loop counter.
statement2 is evaluated before each iteration; if false, the loop stops.
statement3 updates the loop counter after each iteration.
All statements are optional, but the loop body must control termination.

sections.heading: Basic For Loop Example
paragraphs: This example prints numbers from 0 to 4.

sections.heading: For Loop with Step Value
paragraphs: You can change the increment value to control how the loop progresses.
This example counts from 0 to 100 in steps of 10.

sections.heading: The continue Statement
paragraphs: The continue statement skips the current iteration.
The loop then continues with the next iteration.

sections.heading: The break Statement
paragraphs: The break statement immediately terminates the loop.
Execution continues after the loop.

sections.heading: Nested For Loops
paragraphs: A loop inside another loop is called a nested loop.
The inner loop runs once for each iteration of the outer loop.

sections.heading: The range Keyword
paragraphs: The range keyword simplifies iteration over arrays, slices, and maps.
It returns both the index and the value.

sections.heading: Ignoring Index or Value
paragraphs: Use an underscore (_) to ignore either the index or the value.

sections.heading: What is a Function?
paragraphs: A function is a block of code that performs a specific task.
Functions help reduce code repetition and improve readability.
A function does not execute automatically; it runs only when called.

sections.heading: Creating a Function
paragraphs: Functions are declared using the func keyword.
The function name is followed by parentheses ().
The function body is written inside curly braces {}.

sections.heading: Calling a Function
paragraphs: Functions are executed by calling them.
To call a function, write its name followed by parentheses.

sections.heading: Function Called Multiple Times
paragraphs: A function can be reused by calling it multiple times.
Each call executes the function again.

sections.heading: Naming Rules for Functions
paragraphs: A function name must start with a letter.
Only letters, numbers, and underscores are allowed.
Function names are case-sensitive.
Spaces are not allowed in function names.
For multiple words, use camelCase or PascalCase.
Function names should clearly describe what the function does.

sections.heading: Example Output
paragraphs: When the function is called, the code inside it executes and prints output.
sections.code: I just got executed!

sections.heading: Parameters and Arguments
paragraphs: Information can be passed to functions using parameters.
Parameters act like variables inside the function.
Values passed to parameters when calling a function are called arguments.

sections.heading: Function Parameters Syntax
paragraphs: Parameters and their data types are defined after the function name.
Multiple parameters are separated by commas.

sections.heading: Function With One Parameter
paragraphs: This example defines a function with one string parameter.
Different arguments are passed when calling the function.

sections.heading: Example Output
sections.code:
Hello Liam Refsnes
Hello Jenny Refsnes
Hello Anja Refsnes

sections.heading: Parameter vs Argument
paragraphs: Parameters are variables defined in the function declaration.
Arguments are the actual values passed to the function when it is called.
In the example above, fname is a parameter, while Liam, Jenny, and Anja are arguments.

sections.heading: Multiple Parameters
paragraphs: A function can have multiple parameters with different data types.
Arguments must be passed in the same order as parameters.

sections.heading: Multiple Parameters Output
sections.code:
Hello 3 year old Liam Refsnes
Hello 14 year old Jenny Refsnes
Hello 30 year old Anja Refsnes

sections.heading: Important Notes
paragraphs: The number of arguments must match the number of parameters.
Arguments must follow the same order as parameters.
Each parameter must have a defined data type.

sections.heading: Return Values
paragraphs: Functions can return values to the caller.
To return a value, specify the return type and use the return keyword.

sections.heading: Function Return Example
paragraphs: This function receives two integers and returns their sum.

sections.heading: Named Return Values
paragraphs: Go allows naming return values.
Named return values can be returned using a naked return.

sections.heading: Store Return Value
paragraphs: Returned values can be stored in variables.

sections.heading: Multiple Return Values
paragraphs: Go functions can return multiple values.

sections.heading: Ignoring Return Values
paragraphs: Use underscore (_) to ignore unwanted return values.

sections.heading: What is Recursion?
paragraphs: Go supports recursion, which means a function can call itself.
A recursive function must have a stopping condition to prevent infinite execution.

sections.heading: Simple Recursive Function Example
paragraphs: In this example, the function testcount calls itself.
The recursion stops when the value of x becomes 11.

sections.heading: How the Recursion Works
paragraphs: The function prints the current value of x.
Each recursive call increases x by 1.
When x reaches 11, the function stops calling itself.

sections.heading: Why Use Recursion?
paragraphs: Recursion is commonly used in mathematics and programming.
It allows problems to be broken down into smaller, similar sub-problems.
When written correctly, recursion can be efficient and elegant.

sections.heading: Factorial Using Recursion
paragraphs: A factorial function is a classic example of recursion.
The function keeps calling itself until the value reaches zero.

sections.heading: Important Notes on Recursion
paragraphs: Every recursive function must have a base condition.
Without a stopping condition, recursion can lead to infinite loops.
Excessive recursion can consume large amounts of memory and processing power.

sections.heading: What is a Struct?
paragraphs: A struct (structure) is used to group multiple variables of different data types into a single unit.
Unlike arrays, which store values of the same type, structs can store values of different types.
Structs are useful for representing real-world entities as records.

sections.heading: Declaring a Struct
paragraphs: To declare a struct in Go, use the type and struct keywords.
Each struct member has a name and a data type.

sections.heading: Accessing Struct Members
paragraphs: Struct members are accessed using the dot (.) operator.
Each struct variable has its own copy of the data.
sections.code:
package main
import ("fmt")

type Person struct {
  name string
  age int
  job string
  salary int
}

func main() {
  var pers1 Person
  var pers2 Person

  pers1.name = "Hege"
  pers1.age = 45
  pers1.job = "Teacher"
  pers1.salary = 6000

  pers2.name = "Cecilie"
  pers2.age = 24
  pers2.job = "Marketing"
  pers2.salary = 4500

  fmt.Println("Name:", pers1.name)
  fmt.Println("Age:", pers1.age)
  fmt.Println("Job:", pers1.job)
  fmt.Println("Salary:", pers1.salary)

  fmt.Println("Name:", pers2.name)
  fmt.Println("Age:", pers2.age)
  fmt.Println("Job:", pers2.job)
  fmt.Println("Salary:", pers2.salary)
}

sections.heading: Passing Structs to Functions
paragraphs: A struct can be passed as an argument to a function.
When passed normally, Go passes a copy of the struct.

sections.heading: Why Use Structs?
paragraphs: Structs help organize related data together.
They improve code readability and maintainability.
Structs are heavily used in real-world Go applications.

sections.heading: What is a Map?
paragraphs: Maps store data in key:value pairs.
Maps are unordered, changeable, and do not allow duplicate keys.
Maps use a hash table internally and store references to it.
The default value of a map is nil.

sections.heading: Creating Maps Using var and :=
paragraphs: Maps can be created using the var keyword or the := shorthand syntax.
The order of map elements is not guaranteed.

sections.heading: Creating Maps Using make()
paragraphs: The make() function is the recommended way to create empty maps.
Maps created with make() are ready for use immediately.

sections.heading: Nil Maps
paragraphs: A map declared without make() is nil.
Writing to a nil map causes a runtime panic.

sections.heading: Accessing Map Elements
paragraphs: Map elements are accessed using their keys.
If a key does not exist, the zero value is returned.
sections.code: value := myMap[key]

sections.heading: Updating and Adding Elements
paragraphs: Maps allow adding new elements and updating existing ones using assignment.
sections.code: mapName[key] = value

sections.heading: Deleting Map Elements
paragraphs: Elements can be removed from a map using the delete() function.
sections.code: delete(mapName, key)

sections.heading: Checking if a Key Exists
paragraphs: The comma-ok idiom is used to check if a key exists in a map.
This avoids confusion with zero values.
sections.code: val, ok := mapName[key]

sections.heading: Maps Are Reference Types
paragraphs: Maps are reference types.
Assigning one map to another copies the reference, not the data.
sections.code: b := a // both refer to the same map

sections.heading: Iterating Over Maps
paragraphs: Maps can be iterated using the range keyword.
The iteration order is not guaranteed.

sections.heading: Iterating Maps in a Specific Order
paragraphs: Maps are unordered.
To iterate in a fixed order, store keys in a slice and loop over it.
